abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows; Project
            outcome is unsatisfactory, sustainability is unlikely,
            Institutional development impact is modest, Bank performance
            is unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance is
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included the following: 1) A
            high level of ownership and commitment is critical for
            public sector reform. Public sector projects are different
            as reform/change is the heart of the project. It is not
            possible to successfully implement a public sector reform
            project without complete ownership of and commitment to the
            program within government.  2) Credible evidence of
            political commitment to the difficult aspects of the reform
            should be available at the time of appraisal. In the case of
            a change in government, continuation of the project (in this
            case, extension) should be subject to similar indications of
            commitment. 3) For difficult public sector reform projects,
            it might be a good idea to keep the project life within the
            life of the government. In any event, starting
            implementation such a short time before elections (about a
            year in this case) is not prudent. 4) It most cases it might
            be too much to expect sustained commitment to reform over an
            eleven year period. Although, in the circumstances, the
            choice of the APL instrument mitigated this risk it might
            have been more prudent to test commitment with a 2-3 year
            pilot. 5) The implementing and coordinating agency needs to
            have suitable authority. 6) Keep the project focused. The
            scope of the project should be limited to components that
            are inter-related and within which there is a synergy. 7)
            Linkages between components of a reform and the sequencing
            of those reforms need to be recognized at design and
            implementation stage. 8) Appropriate monitoring and
            evaluation mechanisms are required to monitor the impact of
            the reforms. 9) For consultancy-intensive projects the
            supply side is of critical importance.
